deliberation: Looked for non-literal uses. The core image is sin as something inscribed on the heart with an iron stylus and on altar horns. This is not literal writing on internal organs; it functions as a metaphor for deep, permanent guilt. No other distinct figures appear.

instances.hebrew_text: חַטַּאת יְהוּדָה כְּתוּבָה בְּעֵט בַּרְזֶל בְּצִפֹּרֶן שָׁמִיר חֲרוּשָׁה עַל־לוּחַ לִבָּם
instances.english_text: The guilt of Judah is inscribed with a stylus of iron, engraved with an adamant point on the tablet of their hearts
target: The enduring inner guilt of Judah
vehicle: Inscription with an iron stylus on a tablet
ground: Permanence, depth, and unerasability
their sin is deeply impressed and not easily removed
shared qualities of lasting marks
instances.explanation: Judah's sin is pictured as if it were physically engraved with iron on the inner 'tablet' of the heart, conveying the depth and permanence of their guilt.

deliberation: Considered whether 'children remember' and 'verdant trees / lofty hills' are figurative. They describe literal cultic sites and intergenerational memory of idolatry. No clear metaphor, simile, idiom, or personification beyond vivid description.

Hebrew includes the debated phrase 'harari basadeh', but even if it is 'my mountain in the field' as an epithet for Zion, it still refers to a literal location. 'Heap in the field' is a concrete picture of devastation that can literally occur. I did not find a clearly distinct figurative device the verse hinges on.

The loss of inheritance and serving enemies in an unknown land can be literal exile. The clearly non-literal element is 'you have kindled a fire in my nose/anger that shall burn forever', picturing divine wrath as a blazing fire. The eternity language intensifies the image.

instances.english_text: For you have kindled the flame of My wrath that shall burn for all time
vehicle: A fire kindled and burning perpetually
ground: Intense, consuming, and potentially ongoing destruction
their provocation has ignited severe, lasting judgment
shared qualities of destructive intensity
instances.explanation: The people are said to have 'kindled' a fire in God's anger, picturing divine wrath as a blaze they themselves ignited, whose burning 'forever' heightens the seriousness of the coming punishment.

deliberation: Key clause: 'who makes flesh his arm'. 'Flesh' stands for human beings and 'arm' stands for the source of strength. This is a compact figure combining metonymy and metaphor to depict misplaced trust in human power.

instances.english_text: Who makes mere flesh his strength [lit. his arm]
target: Relying on human beings for security
vehicle: bodily limb as symbol of strength
ground: Perceived strength yet actual fragility and limitation
making vulnerable human power one's main support instead of God
shared idea of an arm as the means of power
instances.explanation: To 'make flesh his arm' portrays trusting human beings as if they were one's main supporting limb, combining 'flesh' as a metonym for mortals and 'arm' as a metaphor for strength.

deliberation: Looked for explicit comparisons: 'he shall be like a bush in the desert' introduces a clear simile that is then elaborated with images of scorched, salty, uninhabited land. These all extend the same comparison of the faithless person to a stunted desert shrub.

instances.english_text: He shall be like a bush in the desert
target: The person who trusts in mortals instead of God
vehicle: A desert bush in a parched, salty wilderness
ground: Barren, exposed, without sustenance or future
lack of flourishing and vulnerability to harsh conditions
shared qualities of lifelessness and isolation
instances.explanation: The man who trusts in human power is explicitly compared to a lonely shrub in the desert, highlighting his spiritual barrenness and lack of blessing.

deliberation: This verse contrasts the cursed man of v.5–6 with the blessed man, but does so propositionally: 'Blessed is the man who trusts in YHWH, whose trust is YHWH.' No explicit image or idiom is used here; it prepares for the simile in v.8.

This verse is a sustained simile: the person who trusts in YHWH is 'like a tree planted by waters' with roots by a stream, unaffected by heat and drought, always fruitful. All the tree and climate imagery extends that one comparison.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָיָה כְּעֵץ שָׁת֣וּל עַל־מַיִם וְעַל־יוּבַל יְשַׁלַּח שׇׁרָשָׁיו ... וְלֹא יָמִישׁ מֵעֲשׂוֹת פֶּרִי
instances.english_text: He shall be like a tree planted by waters, sending forth its roots by a stream ... it does not cease to yield fruit
target: The person who trusts in God
vehicle: A well-watered, deeply rooted, ever-fruitful tree
plant life in a fertile environment
ground: Stability, resilience under adverse conditions, ongoing fruitfulness
the secure, sustained flourishing of the God-trusting person
shared qualities of vitality and productivity
instances.explanation: The trusting person is compared to a tree planted by abundant water, whose rootedness and fruitfulness illustrate the stability and blessing that come from reliance on God.

deliberation: The verse attributes crookedness and incurable sickness to 'the heart'. In Hebrew anthropology, 'heart' already functions metonymically for the inner self (mind, will, motives). The verse uses this established metonym, not an additional simile or metaphor within the line.

instances.english_text: Most devious is the heart; it is perverse [incurably sick]
target: The inner human self—thoughts, will, motives
ground: Central controlling role, hiddenness, complexity
using the bodily heart to stand for the inner person that is morally twisted and hard to diagnose
shared idea of an unseen seat of life and decision
instances.explanation: The 'heart' stands for the whole inner self, functioning as a metonym: it is this inner person that is described as deceitful and desperately sick.

deliberation: Identified two distinct figures: (1) God 'searching the heart' and 'testing the kidneys', where 'heart' and 'kidneys' metonymically denote inner thoughts and feelings, and God is portrayed as an examiner; (2) 'the fruit of his deeds', which metaphorically describes outcomes or recompense as fruit produced by actions.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲנִי יְהוָה חֹקֵר לֵב בֹּחֵן כְּלָיוֹת
instances.english_text: I, the LORD, probe the heart, search the mind [lit. kidneys]
target: Human inner thoughts, motives, and emotions
vehicle: Heart and kidneys examined by a searcher/tester
ground: Hiddenness and depth that require probing, capacity to be examined and evaluated
God's intimate knowledge of the most concealed aspects of a person
shared notion of internal reality accessible to a skilled examiner
posture: Assertion of divine omniscience and justice
rhetorical basis for the coming judgment
instances.explanation: The heart and kidneys, as metonyms for the inner person, are portrayed as being searched and tested by God, picturing Him as one who scrutinizes hidden depths.

instances.english_text: To repay each person according to their own ways, with the proper fruit of their deeds
target: The consequences and recompense for a person's actions
ground: Natural outgrowth and result of a prior cause
deeds are pictured as trees or plants that yield fitting fruit as consequences
shared idea of actions bearing results
instances.explanation: Outcomes of one's deeds are described as 'fruit', suggesting that consequences grow organically and appropriately from prior actions.

deliberation: The structure is an explicit comparison: 'Like a partridge hatching what she did not lay, so is one who makes wealth unjustly.' The bird image and the unjust wealth are two sides of a simile; the later clauses explain the simile's point.

instances.hebrew_text: קֹרֵא דָגַר וְלֹא יָלָד כֵּן עֹשֶׂה עֹשֶׁר וְלֹא בְמִשְׁפָּט
instances.english_text: Like a partridge hatching what she did not lay, so are those who amass wealth by unjust means
target: The person who gains wealth unjustly
vehicle: A partridge incubating eggs it did not lay and losing them
ground: Apparent gain that does not truly belong and will not be retained
illicitly acquired wealth that departs mid-life and exposes the owner as a fool
shared idea of deceiving oneself about what is genuinely one's own
instances.explanation: The unjustly wealthy person is likened to a partridge that broods eggs it did not lay, suggesting that what seems gained will be lost and reveal folly.

deliberation: The address 'Throne of glory, exalted from of old, place of our sanctuary' applies royal-throne imagery to God's presence and temple. God does not literally sit on a chair; 'throne of glory' is a metaphor for divine kingship concentrated at the sanctuary.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּסֵּא כָבוֹד מָרוֹם מֵרִאשׁוֹן מְקוֹם מִקְדָּשֵׁנוּ
instances.english_text: O Throne of Glory exalted from of old, our Sacred Shrine!
target: God's royal presence centered in the sanctuary
ground: Sovereignty, exaltation, stability, and honor
the temple as the locus of God's kingly rule over Israel
shared concept of a throne as the symbol of authority
posture: Praise and acknowledgment of God's kingship
instances.explanation: God's sanctuary is addressed as the 'Throne of Glory', a metaphor that identifies the temple as the seat of His royal, glorious rule.

deliberation: Found two clear metaphors: (1) 'Hope of Israel, YHWH' where God is called Israel's hope; (2) 'they have forsaken YHWH, the fountain of living waters' where God is likened to a spring of fresh water. The phrase about being 'written in the earth' is another image but the translation flattens it; the main figurative weight rests on the two divine epithets.

instances.english_text: O Hope of Israel! O LORD!
target: God as the object and ground of Israel's expectation
vehicle: Hope itself, the thing hoped in
ground: Dependability, future-oriented trust, and exclusive reliance
Israel's destiny is anchored in God as in a sure hope
shared notion of something that guarantees a positive outcome
instances.explanation: Calling YHWH 'the Hope of Israel' treats Him as the very embodiment and ground of Israel's expectations, not just as one who gives hope.

instances.english_text: For they have forsaken the LORD, the Fount of living waters
target: God as the life-giving source for His people
divine–human relation in terms of life-flow
vehicle: A spring or fountain of living (flowing) water
ground: Continuous life-giving supply, refreshment, and indispensability
turning from God is like abandoning the only fresh water source in a dry land
shared qualities of dependence and vitality
posture: Rebuke highlighting the folly of apostasy
rhetorical contrast between God and idols
instances.explanation: The LORD is described as a 'fountain of living waters', portraying Him as the indispensable source of life and refreshment that the people have foolishly abandoned.

deliberation: The verbs 'heal' and 'save' could be broader than physical, but they are standard terms for God's restorative action without an overt image in this verse. 'You are my praise' is a compact theological statement rather than a developed metaphor. I discerned no clearly independent figurative expression here.

The people say, 'Where is the word of YHWH? Let it come now.' Here 'word of YHWH' stands metonymically for the prophesied event, and 'come' is part of the idiomatic 'come to pass'. This is a figurative use of 'word' for its fulfillment.

instances.english_text: Where is the word of the LORD? Let it come to pass!
target: The predicted acts of God in judgment or salvation
vehicle: spoken message treated as an event
ground: Intrinsic connection between divine speech and its realization
using 'word' to stand for the event it guarantees, and its 'coming' for its fulfillment
shared notion of speech that effectively brings reality about
posture: Mocking challenge to the prophet and to God
instances.explanation: The 'word of the LORD' is used metonymically for the prophesied outcome, as the scoffers demand that what was spoken should 'come' or happen.

deliberation: Jeremiah claims he has not 'evaded from being a shepherd after you'. The prophetic role is depicted as shepherding under God. This is the familiar metaphor of leadership as shepherding, here applied to Jeremiah in relation to God and the people.

instances.english_text: But I have not evaded being a shepherd after You
target: Jeremiah's prophetic ministry of leading and caring for the people under God
vehicle: A shepherd following after the chief shepherd
ground: Guidance, care, responsibility, and vulnerability for the flock
Jeremiah's task to lead, warn, and protect the people on God's behalf
shared idea of overseeing and tending others
instances.explanation: Jeremiah describes his ministry as 'shepherding after' God, drawing on the shepherd metaphor for leadership and care of the community.

deliberation: Two complementary predicates are used of God: 'do not be to me for a terror' and 'You are my refuge in a day of calamity.' Each pictures God's relation to Jeremiah through spatial metaphors: God as a frightening force vs. God as a shelter. These are distinct but related metaphors.

instances.english_text: Do not be a cause of dismay to me [lit. do not be to me for a terror]
target: Jeremiah's experience of God's dealings with him
vehicle: A crushing terror or object of horror
ground: Capacity to overwhelm and shatter a person
fear that God's judgment might fall on the prophet himself
shared idea of something that causes dread and collapse
posture: Plea for protection rather than judgment
instances.explanation: Jeremiah asks that God not become for him a 'terror', picturing God as a potential source of overwhelming dread and destruction.

instances.english_text: You are my refuge in a day of calamity
ground: Providing safety, covering, and security against danger
Jeremiah's expectation that God will protect him in times of disaster
shared notion of a place one can flee to
posture: Confession of trust in God's protection
instances.explanation: Calling God 'my refuge' depicts Him as a sheltering place where the prophet can be safe when calamity strikes.

deliberation: Literal 'day of disaster' fits standard prophetic idiom. The vivid phrase 'shatter them with double destruction' draws on imagery of breaking objects and intensifies it with 'double', which functions hyperbolically.

instances.english_text: And shatter them with double destruction
target: The total ruin of Jeremiah's persecutors
vehicle: Breaking something into pieces, and that in a 'double' way
ground: Severity, irreversibility, and intensity of the coming judgment
their downfall will be as if smashed beyond repair and even 'doubly' so
shared idea of complete breakage
posture: rhetorical call for decisive divine action
instances.explanation: The persecutors' fate is pictured as being broken with a 'double breaking', a metaphor and hyperbole for extremely severe and irreversible ruin.

deliberation: Narrative instruction to stand in a specific gate by which kings enter and leave. The 'People's Gate' and 'gates of Jerusalem' function literally as architectural features and entry points. No distinct figurative language detected.

The command 'Hear the word of the LORD' is formulaic; 'hear' covers both listening and obeying, but that semantic extension is standard and not a developed metaphor here. The rest is straightforward address. No discrete figurative expression stands out.

The main content is literal Sabbath law. The phrase 'Guard yourselves with your souls/lives' is an idiomatic Hebrew way of saying 'be very careful for your own sake', not about literal soul-guarding. This idiom functions figuratively.

instances.english_text: Guard yourselves for your own sake [lit. guard yourselves with your souls]
target: The people's careful observance of Sabbath regulations
ground: Taking active care to avoid danger or guilt
by watching themselves they will avoid violating the Sabbath and incurring judgment
shared idea of protecting something precious from harm
posture: rhetorical emphasis on consequences for the audience
instances.explanation: The idiom 'guard yourselves with your souls' urges the people to take great care, picturing obedience to Sabbath commands as self-protective vigilance over their very lives.

deliberation: The verse lists concrete Sabbath prohibitions and the command to 'hallow' the day. While consecration is a theological concept, it is not developed via a specific image here. No distinct metaphor, simile, or idiom emerges beyond standard legal language.

Two well-known Hebrew body-part idioms are used: 'they did not incline their ear' meaning they refused to pay attention, and 'they stiffened their neck' meaning they were stubborn. Each is a separate figurative expression based on physical posture to describe inner attitude.

instances.english_text: They would not turn their ear
target: The people's refusal to pay attention to God's commands
vehicle: Physically inclining or turning one's ear toward a speaker
ground: Directing oneself to hear and heed vs. turning away
their failure to listen is expressed as not giving God their ear
shared notion of bodily orientation representing inner attentiveness
instances.explanation: The idiom 'not incline the ear' pictures the people's refusal to heed God's word as a deliberate failure to turn their ear toward the speaker.

instances.english_text: They stiffened their necks
target: Israel's stubborn, unyielding attitude toward God's discipline
vehicle: A neck that is rigid and will not bend
ground: Resistance to turning or bowing, refusal to submit
their unwillingness to change course or humble themselves before God
shared qualities of rigidity and unresponsiveness
instances.explanation: The expression 'stiffened their neck' metaphorically depicts the people as refusing to bend or yield, an idiom for stubborn resistance.

deliberation: Again, the focus is on literal Sabbath behavior: not bringing burdens through the gates, sanctifying the day by ceasing from work. No distinct metaphor, simile, or idiom appears beyond the legal-ritual terminology already explained elsewhere.

The verse promises that kings will enter Jerusalem's gates, sitting on the throne of David, with people and officials. While 'throne of David' is a dynastic expression, it functions here as literal royal seat and line. The city 'shall be inhabited forever' is theological promise but not clearly exaggerated for effect. I did not isolate a discrete figurative device.

This verse describes people coming from real regions bringing various sacrifices and offerings to the house of the LORD. The sacrificial terms are technical cultic language, not deployed figuratively here. No metaphor, simile, or idiom is prominent.

The threat is of literal fire set in the city gates during judgment. Yet the description that the fire will 'consume' (eat) the fortresses and 'not be quenched' uses personifying language and hyperbolic emphasis typical of prophetic 'unquenchable fire' imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִצַּתִּי אֵשׁ בִּשְׁעָרֶיהָ וְאָכְלָה אַרְמְנוֹת יְרוּשָׁלִַם וְלֹא תִכְבֶּה
instances.english_text: Then I will set fire to its gates; it shall consume the fortresses of Jerusalem, and it shall not be extinguished
target: The devastating, unstoppable judgment on Jerusalem
destruction of city and elite structures
vehicle: A fire that eats (consumes) and cannot be quenched
ground: Total, voracious, and uncontrollable destruction
Jerusalem's palaces and defenses will be destroyed as if devoured by a fire no one can put out
shared qualities of consuming and irreversibility
posture: Severe warning of judgment for Sabbath violation
rhetorical use of fear to enforce obedience
instances.explanation: The coming destruction is portrayed as a fire that 'eats' Jerusalem's fortresses and cannot be quenched, personifying the fire and using hyperbole to stress the inevitability and completeness of the judgment.
